captions.text: Hi. I’m John Green,
This is Crash Course World History

and today we’re going to talk about the
entire frakking globe over the course of several
centuries
so let’s get right to it.
Mr. Green. Frakking?

You don’t know about
Battlestar Galactica yet,
Me From The Past?
Oh, man,
there are so many great

things in your future.
[like Regretsy.com & My Drunk Kitchen]

Today, I’m going to try to show you how
tiny Spain’s influence spread around the

world and shaped the lives of almost every
human on the planet,
generally in negative ways.
I know,

everything is such a bummer
on Crash Course recently.

[Holy Atlantic Slave Trade,
Batman]
It’s the sixteenth century.
People are getting richer,

they’re living more connected lives and
all I can do is whine about how much better
the old days were.
What am I, your grandpa?
Let’s get festive.
Woo.
[intro music]
[intro music]
[intro music]
[intro music]
[intro music]
[intro music]
[intro music]

So the Aztecs weren’t the first impressive
polity in Mesoamerica,
that honor would go to the Olmecs or the Mayans.
But they were probably the greatest.

The Aztecs formed out of an alliance of three
major cities in modern day Mexico in about

just 89 years before Cortez and
his conquistadors showed up.
The Aztec state was very hierarchical,

with an emperor at the top and a
group unruly nobles beneath him.
Just like Europe.
And in addition,

there was a class of powerful priests whose
job it was to keep order in the cosmos.
[like in the 5th Element?]

So, Aztec religion held that history was cyclical
and punctuated by terrible disasters and then
would ultimately end with a massive apocalypse.

And the job of the priests was
to avoid these disasters,
by appeasing the gods,
generally through human sacrifice.

The Aztecs extended their control
over most of southern Mexico,

parts of Guatemala
and the Yucatan.

And they demanded tribute from
conquered people in the form of

goods, precious metals,
and people to sacrifice.

If you’re familiar with
The Hunger Games,

[You are totally familiar
with the Hunger Games...]

it won’t surprise you to learn that this
didn’t sit very well with said conquered
people.

And the fact that the Aztecs were basically
ruling over thousands of people who hated

them made it a lot easier for Cortez to come
in and find allies to overthrow them.
All that noted,
in less than a hundred years,

the Aztecs accomplished
some amazing things.

Especially the building of their
capital city Tenochtitlan,

on the site of
modern day Mexico City,

which was like Venice in that it was divided
and serviced by canals.

They also had floating gardens,
called chinampas,
which provided food for the city.
Oh,
it’s already time for the open letter?
Alright.

[Switches from chair to lemon/lime velvet
throne of impending structural disaster]
An open letter to Human Sacrifice.
But first,

let’s see what’s in the
secret compartment today.
Oh, nice.
Come on.

Be a mushroom, be a mushroom,
be a---
oh dahh.
Dear human sacrifice,
look,
I’m not going to defend you.

But if you really believe that the world is
going to end if the gods are not appeased,

then human sacrifice
kind of makes sense.

[But not if you’re Willie
in Temple of Doom...]
And as evidence for this,
let me submit to you

that we engage in
human sacrifice all the time.

Remember the movie,
The Dirty Dozen?
No?
Because you’re too young?
That makes me hate myself.

[Don’t worry, Johnny Bookwriter,
“vintage” will always be cool.]

Anyway, it was all about glorious sacrifice
and how a few have to die in order for many
to live.

Did you at least see that--
that uh,

meteor movie that
Ben Affleck was in?
What was that called, Stan?

Asteroid.
[Stan, off camera]
Asteroid!

Armageddon.
[Stan, off camera]
Armageddon!
Armageddon.
Right. Like that...
Human sacrifice.
Best wishes, John Green.
Alright,

now let’s head south to
the Inca civilization, which was older than
the Aztecs and in some ways even more impressive.
Founded in the 13th century,

the Inca empire ruled between 4 and 6 million
people by the time the Spanish showed up in

Trade and a very effective administrative
structure held the empire together, which

was even more impressive when you consider
all the roads and temples that were built

atop mountains with nothing to haul things
up those mountains,
except for llamas and people.

[Thought the Mongols
were the exception?]

The Inca had no written language but they
were able to keep records with knotted strings

called quipus.
[Gesundheit!]

And vitally, they ordered every male peasant
under the Inca control to do unpaid work for

the Inca government for a specified period
of time each year.
This system,
which the Inca called mit’a

allowed them to build all those
roads and temples.

The Spanish would later adopt this system,
and the hierarchical system with the emperor
at the top, except they would make it all,
you know,

much suckier.
[Is that a historical term?]
And, yes,
that is a technical historian term.

So, the Spanish arrived in Mexico in 1519,
and in Peru in 1532, benefiting in both cases
from total chaos due to disease.

And after conquering the Incas and the Aztecs,
they created an empire with two administrative
divisions.

The Viceroyalty of New Spain,
founded in 1521,

and the Viceroyalty of Peru,
founded in 1542.
In some ways,

the Aztec and Inca empires were
perfect for Spanish conquest.

Their administrative structures
were similar,

there was a similar link between
secular and religious power,
albeit different religions.

All of which made it relatively easy for the
Spanish crown to step into the void left by

those two great empires and send their own
administrators to run the place.

While most of the Spanish aristocrats who
came over ran large agricultural operations,
you don’t see a lot of movies called, like,

Indiana Jones and the Search for
A Nice Farm in the Countryside.

[Probably still much better than
that Crystal Skull nonsense.]

The real glory for conquistadors
was gold.
Initially they found some,

both in the Caribbean
and in Mexico,
but never enough to get,
like, super-rich.
Fortunately,

or as I will argue,
unfortunately,

they did find a mountain
made of silver.
So the Spanish adapted the mita,

which the Incas had used to build
roads and public buildings,
to mine and process that silver.

So 1/7th of the adult male Indian population
from each district was required to work in
the silver mines for a year,
being paid only subsistence wages.

Now, you might wonder why the Spanish didn’t
purchase African slaves to work in the mines.
They did in Mexico,

but in South America it was cheaper
to use indigenous labor.

Purchasing slaves was
inefficient because

1.
They didn’t have experience working at high
altitudes,

and 2.
Mine work was super deadly.
Mercury,

which can be used to
refine silver ore,

was found at the mountain
of Huancavelica.

And mercury poisoning among miners was so
common that parents would often maim their

children to keep them from having to work
the mines.

You can see why
I’m struggling to be festive!
Let’s go to the Thought Bubble.

[Let’s go see if the Canadians
can zazz things up a bit...]

So Spanish mines in the Americas produced
over 150,000 tons of silver between the 16th

and the 18th centuries, over 80% of the world’s
supply.

Spain became the richest nation in Europe
and Spanish silver pesos became the de-facto
currency.
But the Spanish royal family

does not appear to have
understood inflation—

and the huge influx of silver caused skyrocketing
inflation, and since they never set tax rates

to account for it, they collected the same
amount of money sixty years after the discovery

of silver, but that money was worth a fraction
of what it once had been.
And in general,

it’s not clear that Spain benefited
much from the discovery of silver.

Rich countries have a way of finding their
way into expensive and not totally necessary

wars, and Spain was no exception. While empire
wasn’t the central cause of Spain’s many
16th century wars,
it sure did fund them.
So in 1519

(which was a heck of
a year for Spain)

Charles V united the kingdoms of Spain and
Austria by being named head of the Holy Roman
Empire,
so called because
it was not Holy,
not Roman,
and not an Empire.

Charles had this dream of a unified central
Europe, which was constantly being thwarted

by German nobles, who had a dream of a non-unified
central Europe, and eventually Charles V’s

ambitions were shattered and he gave the Austrian
half of his kingdom to his son Ferdinand and

gave Spain with the American stuff to Philip
in 1556.
Thanks, Thought Bubble.

So, Philip II didn’t only inherited all
of Spain’s holdings in the Americas and
in Europe and in the

Phillip-not-a-coincidence-ines.
[Dedicated to that reach, eh?]

He also inherited a rebellion
in the Netherlands,
because the Dutch were like,

“We’re gonna be Protestant, also you
guys know nothing about economics,”
which, incidentally,

the Dutch are still saying
to the Spanish.

And then the English sided with the Dutch
and there was a war featuring a disastrous
invasion of England,
called the Spanish Armada,

England’s success against the Spanish, even
though it can largely be chalked up to the
weather,

was credited to queen Elizabeth I.
[Like a boss, even still.]

That led to a period of wealth and national
pride, which meant that people had both the
money and the desire to see,
I don’t know,

plays about old English Kings
named Richard.
And that, my friends,

is how the discovery of silver in Bolivia
contributed to the genius of William Shakespeare.
[And Kevin Bacon?]
Anyway,

American silver didn’t
cause these wars
anymore than it wrote Hamlet,

but the new wealth made
both more possible.

Knowing that they had this enormous silver
“war chest” at their disposal made them

much more inclined to build all those ships
that got sunk in 1588.

And soon enough even a mountain of silver
could not pay for all the warring, and the

Spanish crown had to borrow money, which they
couldn’t pay back, so they defaulted on
their debt several times in the 17th century.
Yay, silver.
So,

most of the silver mined in the
Americas went to Europe,
but at least a third of it went to China.
Either directly,
on Spanish galleons,

or indirectly through through the
purchase of Chinese goods.

China had encountered inflation of its own
after printing the world’s first paper money
in the 12th century,
so they switched back to coins.
Initially,

Chinese coins were made out of
copper or bronze,
but their economy was so big—

they were the leading producer of consumer
goods until the 19th century—
that they ran out.
So they went to silver.

Now, China didn’t have a lot
of silver itself,
but Japan did,

so they traded manufactured
goods for it,
but soon even that wasn’t enough.

This was mostly because in the 16th century,
China changed its tax structure.
Taxes, man,

they’re at the center of human history.
[Progress doesn’t fund itself, yo.]

In the early part of the Ming Dynasty, Chinese
farmers paid their taxes in goods, mainly
grain, and labor.

But as more silver entered the economy, the
Ming government changed its policy and required
taxes to be paid in silver.

This meant that almost everyone in China had
to produce something that could be sold for
silver,
which usually meant silk.
In fact,

the Ming government often required
people to make silk.

That glut of silk inevitably led to a price
drop, which hurt the Chinese economy but not

nearly as much as it hurt the Spanish economy,
where almost every silk producer was put out
of business.

So much for the idea that global outsourcing
is a new problem.

You’d think all this silver would
make the Chinese incredibly rich,
just like the Spanish, right?

Well, yes, just like the Spanish,
in that they got rich,
they didn’t stay rich.

The Ming government also failed
to peg taxes to inflation,
and spent too much on defense,
notably on the Great Wall.

And by the 17th century the Ming were overthrown
by the Fu Manchus.
Oh,
it’s just the Manchus?
Gah.
History, always disappointing me.
As the historian Dennis Flynn put it,

“A significant hunk of the GDP of China
– then the world’s biggest economy – was

surrendered in order to secure a white metal
that was produced mostly in Spanish America
and Japan.

…Think about what else those resources could
have been used for.” #

The Spanish empire’s silver trade was the
first truly global market—
even India was involved,
but we’re really out of time—
and its consequences are dire,
even if it did make some people rich.

Both Spain and China experienced inflation
that weakened their governments.
The environment suffered.

The search for precious metals led the Spanish
to find and eventually destroy two of the
world’s great empires,
the Aztecs and the Inca.

And many thousands were killed mining silver
and the mercury used to refine it.
But before you say it wasn’t worth it,

remember that this process led
to the life that you have today,

one where I can teach you history
through the magic of the Internet.
Worth the sacrifices,
human and otherwise?
I don’t know. You tell me.
Thanks for watching.
See you next week.
Crash Course is

produced and directed
by Stan Muller.

Our script supervisor is
Danica Johnson.
The show is written by

my high school history teacher
Raoul Meyer and myself,

and our graphics team
is Thought Bubble.

Last week’s phrase of the week was
“number four, letter u”

if you want to suggest future phrases
of the week or guess at this week’s

you can do so in comments,
where you can also ask questions

that will be answered by
our team of historians.
Thanks for watching Crash Course,
and as we say in my hometown,

Don’t Forget, You may be cool,
but you’re no Neil DeGrasse Tyson.

title: The Spanish Empire, Silver, & Runaway Inflation: Crash Course World History #25

comments.text:

don't even know about the existence of the "Black Legend". The Spanish 
dollar was the most valued and stable currency in the world, it was also 
the most commonly used coin in trade. The Spanish dollar was widely used by 
many countries as international currency because of its uniformity in 
standard and milling characteristics. Some countries countersigned the 
Spanish dollar so it could be used as their local currency.The Spanish 
dollar was the coin upon which the original United States dollar was based. 
Because it was widely used in Europe, the Americas, and the Far East, it 
became the first world currency by the late 18th century. Aside from the 
U.S. dollar, several other existing currencies, such as the Canadian 
dollar, the Japanese yen, the Chinese yuan, the Philippine peso, and 
several currencies were initially based on the Spanish dollar.

comments.text:
There are so many mistakes in this video I can barely answer all of them:

-The spanish founded hospital, universities, and many cities, in where the 
natives could be healed, learn and live in much better conditions than 
before. The indian laws were respected, unless it meant things like human 
sacrifice (US antophologist Marvin Harris said that "the human sacrifice 
scale practised in Tenochticlan has no parallel in all human History"), and 
native chiefs were recognized as hispacin aministrators in order to protect 
the most the precolombian societies.

- The king Charles I stopped the conquest in order to decide if Spain had 
right or not to make it (Who, in all human History, made something like 
this!?). He joined the wise men of this century and made them think about 
it: as a result, the first human rights were born ("derecho de gentes", as 
James Brown Scott said: "I, James Brow Scott, anglosazon and protestant, 
declare fray Francisco of Vitoria, spanish, catholic and dominic monk, as 
the true founder of the modern school of International Law").

-The first 8-hours work day was first enjoyed by native miners in América, 
as a law made by Philippe II, king of Spain, in the XVI century.

-In percentage, died more spanish due to hard acclimatation and strange 
illness in América (50%) than native american due to european flu (20-30%). 
- Spanish colonies had democratic representation in Spanish Cortes 
(parliament), not as english ones.

- Spanish inquisition could not judge native americans (nor pagans it was 
not made for that neither catholics -they considered them as new faith men, 
with more rights than peninsular spanish-). - Encomienda (social system of 
work distribution), was made with some mistakes at first, but it ended 
being far softer than the analog sytem in Europe.

I could keep going, but I preffer to recommend some GOOD history authors 
for being read by interested ones: Philip W. Powell, Jean Dumont, José 
Antonio Vaca de Osma, Stanley G. Payne...﻿

comments.text:
La principal causa de mortalidad de las poblaciones nativas se produjo por 
las enfermedades que llevaron los españoles, no por un exterminio planeado 
previamente. Además, los españoles tenían dos principales intereses en 
aquellas tierras: los metales preciosos y la evangelización, tarea ésta 
última en la que fueron muy eficaces. ¿Y saben por qué? Porque los 
misioneros españoles aprendieron las lenguas nativas para poder enseñar la 
"verdadera" fe. De hecho, al contrario de lo que se suele creer, los 
españoles nunca impusieron el castellano a los nativos. Fueron los propios 
criollos independentistas, influidos por las ideas ilustradas del XVIII, 
los que cuando consiguen la independencia de aquellas tierras imponen la 
enseñanza del castellano. Cualquier libro de historia del español lo 
confirma. (De hecho, los pasquines independentistas se editaron en lenguas 
indígenas porque eran la mayoría de la población, la cuál era católica pero 
no tenía absoluta idea del castellano).
Por supuesto, no voy a decir que los españoles de entonces no hicieran 
barbaridades con los nativos. Desde luego que se hicieron. Explotaciones

comments.author: Tomas Engle

comments.text:
The problem with the black legend is not that it is false.  The Spanish 
Empire was awful.  It was detrimental, to the natives, a haven for the 
institution of slavery, witnessed cultural and in some cases complete 
ethnic genocide, and planted the seeds of of the distorted ethno-class 
structures that still plague Latin America today.  The problem with the 
black legend is that it is treated as exceptional, whereas the British and 
French Empires were just as brutal, as well as the Dutch and Portuguese 
colonies, the Belgian Congo, etc.  

Criticizing the Spanish empire is not a criticism of Spain, Europe, or the 
West.  It is a criticism of Empire.  It is a criticism of what they did, 
not who they are.  I think the Spanish conquest represents one of the 
greatest worst calamities to ever befall human kind.  But I also think that 
the Spanish people represent many of the greatest things humanity has to 
offer, and I find their history, their culture, and their politics 
fascinating.  I repeat, the Spanish Empire represents something the Spanish 
did, not who the Spanish are, and it can't be held against them anymore 
than the holocaust can be held against Germans, or the genocide of American 
Indians against Americans.  But that doesn't mean it didn't happen, and it 
should be remembered and condemned so that it is never perpetrated again by 
anyone towards anyone.  .  ﻿

comments.author: Christopher Bieszad

comments.text:
As short as I can:

- Muslims invade Spain. 700 years of wars. In the end, muslims expelled and 
country reconquered in the name of Christianity. Society is heavy 
militarized and religious.

- The *SAME* year in which the war ends, America is discovered. Religious 
and military leaders are sent abroad. They find pagans cutting out hearts 
of other conquered tribes. I mean, what do you expect will happen? These 
are people who have been warring all their life, for dozens of generations, 
and are as Christian as you can get.

- Goal: Liberate conquered tribes, destroy pagans, work the mines. They do 
it. The Queen passes a law that forbids from enslaving the natives and 
tells to treat them as Spanish, as long as they convert. 80% of the 
governors in the Americas ignore this. A few governors get caught, 
arrested, and put to death (Colombus being a prime example; he wasn't put 
to death because of his services to the crown, but he was arrested and 
stripped of his titles and riches).

- The general tone, however, is that common people marry and have children 
with the natives, and it is common for the natives to marry a Spaniard to 
rise in the social scale. Once a native becomes Christian and learns 
Spanish, he/she is considered Spanish.

- Some viceroys and nobles choose to obey the Crown fully, and black slaves 
are brought from Africa, since Native Americans are Spanish and can't be 
enslaved (Rennaissance logic, not much to say about that, but hey, our 
actual colonies weren't that bad). This is not common, though (as evidenced 
by the fact that there are not so many blacks in central and South America, 
especially if you compare with the English Caribbean colonies, which are 
almost fully populated by blacks).

- The Spanish proceed to wipe their asses with Europe, with their 
newly-acquired riches and millitary tradition of great generals, 
"centuries-at-war" hardened soldiers, and powerful tactics, very advanced 
for their time.

- Eventually, after 200 years, the Empire starts its decadence. Bitter, 
butthurt enemies create the "Black Legend", an old "Internet meme" of some 
sorts about our country being evil in its purest form.

- Their Empires fight wars against ours. Thousands of our American natives 
fight on the side of Spain to avoid being conquered by the British (I 
wonder why, since we were so terrible, right?). The British proceed to 
obliterate the North American indians, among other things, but in the end 
they write history.

Nowadays:
- General opinion: Spanish Empire, bad bad bad. British Empire, good good 
good.
- South American natives alive today (speaking spanish): 200 million, most 
of them mixed, with Spanish ancestry.
- North American natives alive today: 3 million, in reservations.

I rest my case. Thanks for your interest.

argument are able to discern the atrocities committed by the indigenous 
peoples to each other as well as the atrocities committed by Europeans. 
Moreover, we make it very clear to each other that we also respect and 
understand the positive contributions the meeting of cultures gave to the 
world. History is not black and white. There are no heroes or villains in 
the story of man. We are a people of grey morals who are capable of both

comments.text:
Haha, so it was ok for the Incas to do the Mit'a, but it was not ok when 
the spaniards did it? Talk about hipocrisy to satanize Spain's deed in 
America. You say the unified "Holy Roman Empire" was not an empire. ¿What? 
it was "Holy" in the sense of having the support of the Pope (most of the 
time though, Charles V had struggles with his contemporary Pope, which 
Charles won after the sack of Rome). Ok, I'll give it to you it wasn't 
"Roman". But it was an Empire. First let's define empire. In my dictionary 
I found this: lands ruled by single authority: a group of nations, 
territories, or peoples ruled by a single authority, especially an emperor 
or empress. And the Dictionary of the Royal Spanish Academy (DRAE in 
spanish) says: "Conjunto de Estados sujetos a un emperador", now you migh 
as well translate that, but it's basically the same definition.

And yeah, classic that an anglo-centered historian talks about Spain's 
failures, but "inexplicably" doesn't talk much of Spain's goals, as 
basically defending Europe from the Ottomans at the battle of Lepanto. And 
also you talk about english literature in a video about Spain? Ever heard 
of the "Siglo de Oro"? Or even Cervantes with El Quijote?

It also doesn't make any sense, you try to justify the sacrifices made by 
the aztecs, which stopped after the evangelization of the indigenous 
people. AND, it is proven that it wasn't a violent imposition, the 
indigenoud were excited about this religion which was new to them, and 
adopted it gladly. Now there were incidents obviously, but when talking in 
general, now, I do make a point. ANd if you bring up the inquisiton, 
please, compare the number of the inquisition to that of the human 
sacrifices.

And the Viceroyalty of Peru wasn't as big as you portrayed it to be, there 
were other two Viceroyalties there. The Viceroyalty of Nueva Granada 
(modern day Venezuela, Colombia and Ecuador), and The Viceroyalty of Rio de 
la Plata (Modern day Chile, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay I think). Also, 
gre way to go talking about the deaths of indigenous people, but not how 
they actually mixed with the spaniards, thing that barely happened in the 
english colonies. Also Guatemala is more towards the southeast. Now we can 
see here the stereotype of the United States' ignorance in geography.

Also it is great how you don't talk about how everything started with 
Isabel the Catholic, which unified Spain into one entity, instead you talk 
about Elizabeth.. yuck. You also say "Most of the silver mines in the 
Americas went to Europe". Seriously? The quinto real which was the 20% of 
the wealth produced went to Spain, the other 80% stayed in America, the 
money was used to build roads, aqueducts, universities (Yes, you heard it, 
real fucking universities, which FYI, only the Spanish did it in the 
americas long before the british), harbors, and forts, and permanent armies 
to defend the Viceroyalties, these last two made to defend from british and 
french pirates. Finally, get this, a Viceroyalty is not the same as a 
colony, the viceroyalty is basically another part of the metropolis, and a 
colony is merely seen as a fabric for goods.

In conclusion, this is just another way to satanize the spanish made for 
ignorants who won't read history by theselves. You want to learn history 
for real? READ BY YOURSELF. Aaaand, before you call me a spanish butthurt, 
I'm from Veracruz, Mexico. A city founded by the great Cortes, the first 
city in mainland América. I'm proud of my hispanic heritage, proud of being 
an hispano, not a "latino" term invented by the french to divide even more 
us hispanics.

Peace out.﻿

comments.text:
De Arturo Perez-Reverte;
Pues ahí estábamos, con el mundo por montera o más bien siendo montera del 
mundo: la España de Carlos V, con dos cojones, un pie en América, otro en 
el Pacífico, lo de en medio en Europa y allá a su frente Estambul, o sea, 
el imperio turco, con el que andábamos a bofetadas en el Mediterráneo un 
día sí y otro también, porque con sus piratas y sus corsarios del norte de 
África y su expansión por los Balcanes era la única potencia de categoría 
que nos miraba de cerca, y no compares. Los demás estaban achantados, 
incluido el papa de Roma, al que le íbamos recortando los poderes 
temporales en Italia una cosa mala y nos tenía unas ganas tremendas, pero 
no le quedaba otra que tragar bilis y esperar tiempos mejores. Por aquella 
época, con eso de la expansión española, el imperio que crecía en América y 
las nuevas tierras descubiertas por la expedición de Magallanes y Elcano al 
dar la vuelta al mundo, los españoles teníamos la posibilidad, en vez de 
malgastar nuestra mala leche congénita en destriparnos entre vecinos, de 
volcarla por ahí afuera, conquistando cosas, dando por saco y yendo como 
nos gusta, de nuevos ricos y sobrados por encima de nuestras posibilidades: 
Yo no sé de dónde saca / p'a tanto como destaca, que luego dijo la 
zarzuela, o la copla, o lo que fuera. Y claro, la peña nos odiaba como es 
de imaginar; porque guapos no sé, pero oro y plata de las Indias, chulería 
y ejércitos imbatidos y temibles aquellos tercios viejos teníamos para dar 
a todos las suyas y las del pulpo; y quien tenía algo que perder buscaba 
congraciarse con esos animales morenos, bajitos, crueles y arrogantes que 
tenían al orbe agarrado por la entrepierna, haciendo realidad lo que luego 
resumió algún poeta de cuyo nombre no me acuerdo: Y simples soldados rasos 
/ en portentosa campaña / llevaron el sol de España / desde el oriente al 
ocaso. Porque háganse idea: sólo en Europa, teníamos la península ibérica 
(Portugal estaba a punto de nieve, porque Carlos V, encima, se casó con una 
princesa de allí que se rompía de lo guapa que era), Cerdeña, Nápoles y 
Sicilia, por abajo; y por arriba, ojo al dato, el Milanesado, el 
Francocondado que era un trozo de la actual Francia, media Suiza, las 
actuales Bélgica, Holanda, Alemania y Austria, Polonia casi hasta Cracovia, 
los Balcanes hasta Croacia y un cacho de Checoslovaquia y Hungría. Así que 
calculen con qué ojos nos miraba la peña, y qué ganas tenían todos de que 
nos agacháramos a coger el jabón en la ducha. El que peor nos miraba, 
turcos aparte hasta con ellos pactó para hacernos la cama, el muy cabrón, 
era el rey de Francia, un chulito guaperas de quiero y no puedo llamado 
Francisco I, cursi que te mueres, con mucho quesquesevú y mucho 
quesquesesá. Y François, que así se llamaba el pavo en gabacho, le tenía a 
nuestro emperata Carlos una envidia horrorosa, comprensible por otra parte, 
y estuvo dando la brasa con territorios por aquí e Italia por allá, hasta 
que el ejército español es un decir, porque allí había de todo le dio una 
estiba horrorosa en la batalla de Pavía, con el detalle de que el rey 
franchute cayó en manos de una compañía de arcabuceros vascos a los que 
tuvo que rendirse, imaginen el diálogo, errenditú barrabillak (o te rindes 
o te corto los huevos, en traducción libre: de Hernani era el energúmeno 
que le puso la espada en el pescuezo), y el monarca parpadeando 
desconcertado, preguntándose a quién carajo se estaba rindiendo y si se 
habría equivocado de guerra. Al fin se rindió, qué remedio, y acabó 
prisionero en Madrid, en la torre de los Lujanes, justo al lado de la casa 
donde hoy vive Javier Marías. Pero bonito, lo que se dice bonito, y que 
también pasó en Italia, fue lo del papa: éste se llamaba Clemente VII, y 
podríamos resumirlo psicológicamente diciendo que era un hijo de puta con 
balcones a la plaza de San Pedro, traidor y tacaño, dado a compadrear con 
Francia y a mojar en toda conspiración contra España. Pero le salió el 
chino mal capado, porque en 1527, por razones que ustedes pueden encontrar 
detalladas en los libros de Historia véase Saco de Roma, el ejército 
imperial (seis mil españoles que imagínenselos, diez mil alemanes puestos 
de cerveza hasta las trancas y marcando el paso de la oca, dos mil 
flamencos y otros tantos italianos hablando con su mamma por teléfono) tomó 
por asalto las murallas de Roma, hizo 40.000 muertos sin despeinarse y 
saqueó la ciudad durante meses. Y no colgaron al papa de una farola porque 
el vicario de Cristo, remangándose la sotana, corrió a refugiarse en el 
castillo de Sant'Angelo. Lo que, la verdad, no deja de tener su puntito﻿

comments.text:
Because the English and the French (and those who followed them: Americans, 
Canadians, Australians) always like to shame the Spanish for what they did, 
for how horrible they were, etc. When what they did was far worse, and I 
know at least in America, they treat these English colonizers like heroes 
and the Spanish like assholes. And I don't think any Hispanic (Latinos too) 
denies that what Spain did was pretty fucked up. However, I myself am 1/4 
Indian (I'm latinamerican) and I think that in a way, their reign resulted 
much better for the natives as in English colonies. Look at the U.S.: 
There's almost no natives left anywhere, they live in scattered little 
reservations with little resources. Look at a country like Mexico: Yes, the 
natives still do live in generally more poverty as the whites, but they're 
slowly being made equal. And look at all the mixed race people there, too. 
They're also rising more and more to equality. At least they're still 
there, and they were assimilated, but they're culture has in a way 
survived, though mixed with Spanish culture. Look again at any Anglo 
colonial country: almost no natives, and the natives which are there have 
been pushed away from the white colonizers and their cultures have had 
almost no influence on the culture of the now white majorities in those 
countries. Now tell me again that the Spanish treated their natives worse 
than the Anglos. They at least survived and were assimilated and now make 
up a majority in most latinamerican countries. The Anglos however, had a 
racist and xenophobic policy of killing every native they saw until they 
went away. And yet most anglo countries simply don't talk about it, or deny 
it altogether. And the Australians as an example still treat their natives 
like shit. So again before you Anglos want to insult us Hispanics and try 
demonizing our ancestors as murderers and slavers, look back at your own 
history and see that what you guys did is just as bad if not worse.

no te pueda enviar en una cápsula del tiempo pa'llá, desgraciado...! Ibas 
a estar suplicando de rodillas que un hidalgo español te rescatase de esos 
dioses del terror y besarías la estampa de una reina digna como Isabel que 
siempre ordenó y dejó escrito en su testamento que a los indígenas (no 
católicos) se les dispensara el mismo trato que a cualquier español. Para 
la historia queda ya nuestro imperio y el de todos los que se sienten o 
sintieron leales españoles, pero también quedan nuestras hazañas de leyenda 
(El Cid, La Reconquista, El Descubrimiento, Lepanto, El Gran Capitán, La 
vuelta al mundo de Magallanes, Rocroix, La oreja de Jenkins, El 
Levantamiento del 2 de Mayo, Los 14 de la fama, Los últimos de Filipinas, 
etc.), y para el futuro... la reconquista de América a través de nuestro 
idioma (actual lengua mayoritaria de América) que se abre camino en los 
Estados Unidos y que muchas proyecciones demográficas apuntan a que se 
convertirá en la lengua materna de 1/3 de los estadounidenses a finales de 
este siglo. Vuestro racismo es la leña en la que prende nuestro idioma, y 
nuestra inmigración incesante es la corriente de aire que lo mantendrá 
ardiente.﻿

comments.text:
+Bastián Rodríguez El lio religioso se lo dejo a gusto de cada quien, pero 
desde luego que considero una mejora una religion que valora las 
ensenianzas de un maestro que camino hace 2mil anios impartiendo lecciones 
que, si leyeras la biblia (al menos el nuevo testamento) verias que le 
sirven de mucho hasta a un ateo, que una que adora a una estrella que pide 
que le sacrifiquen ninios. Luego, no entiendo tu complejo con el 
"capitalismo salvaje" como le dices, si es ese mismo capitalismo el que nos 
llevo a producir los bienes de los que gozamos hoy en dia, incluyendo la 
computadora por la que me escribes: nunca la humanidad fue tan rica como 
hoy, nunca produjo tantos alimentos, nunca produjo tanta tecnologia y nunca 
produjo tanto conocimiento ni encontro cura a tantas enfermedades. 
Preguntas que tendria de malo no ser parte de eso? Pues para comenzar 
tendrias que despedirte de tu computadora, irte a vivir al campo a cosechar 
18 horas al dia (apuesto a que nunca lo has hecho), despedirte de la ropa 
que vistes pues las economias precolombinas solo podian permitir al hombre 
comun usar un calzon de paño (esto es un trapo pasado por delante y por 
detras, amarrado con una pita. Asi es, la gente ordinaria no andaba 
cubierta de oro de pies a cabeza mismo señor de Sipan ni las enterraban con 
25 sirvientes) y, si te enfermas, caballero nomas a curarte con un cuy y 
sacarte el mal con piedras tibias porque eso es la medicina andina (como 
ves, no todo lo que es raices culturales, vale la pena conservar...a donde 
mandarian a un doctor si quisiera curarte con piedras tibias? al sanatorio 
mental, obvio). El capitalismo tiene un lado feo que es el de no dar cura a 
la pobreza de la gente menos favorecida, pero la pobreza es mucho mas 
antigua y universal que el capitalismo...  Y eso de que las potencias 
europeas vinieron solo a destruir y que el comercio en cambio nos habria 
homologado...bueno la mayor parte de las muertes fueron de la enfermedades 
del viejo continente que llegaron con los colonos y eso habria sucedido 
eventualmente ya sea por comercio o por colonizacion porque el contacto con 
el resto del mundo es inevitable, si no llegaban los espanioles, habrian 
llegado los ingleses, los portugueses, franceses, holandeses, chinos o los 
indios americanos mismos habrian terminado viajando (probablemente a China) 
y trayendo enfermedades consigo...los espanioles simplemente llegaron 
primero...No hay que ver la historia con ese complejo victimista, esas son 
excusas para poner nuestras deficiencias como sociedad y el deber de 
solucionarlos en los hombros de gente que murio hace mas de 300 anios en 
lugar de los nuestros. Para ponerte un contexto, el Japon de hoy existe 
solo desde el final de la segunda guerra mundial, la Italia moderna se 
forma en la segunda mitad del siglo XIX, lo mismo que Alemania; todas ellas 
han construido economias mucho mas fuertes y sociedades mas prosperas que 
las latino americanas que tienen 200 anios de existencia libre y otros 300 
mas al menos como unidades politicas bajo la colonia, y dudo que eso sea 
para culpar a los espanioles.
comments.author: Niidea1986

comments.text:
+Niidea1986 Y que tendría de malo no ser parte del irracional ciclo del 
capitalismo masivo que han creado las "culturas más avanzadas"?. Lo más 
seguro es que por comercio y relaciones de intercambio positivo, América se 
habría estandarizado de todas formas, manteniendo sus raíces culturales. En 
cambio las potencias colonizadoras llegaron a destruir este proceso, a 
enriquecerse a costa de miles de humanos y a proclamar la existencia de un 
dios falso y pagano como todos los demás. Saludos.
comments.author: Bastián Rodríguez

comments.text:
+Zui Marie Hola. A cuantos pedofilos conoces personalmente? Cuantos son 
sacerdotes/pastores? Ninguno probablemente, y te voy a decir por que: 
porque no todo sacerdote es pedofilo ni todo pedofilo es cristiano; asi que 
no hables como si asi fuera o algun lugar de la biblia defendiera esa 
aberracion (hablando de extremismos...). Me preguntaste si tengo un 
problema con que los incas adoraran al sol; tengo 2: el sol es una estrella 
no un dios y ni el ni otras huacas (dioses andinos) vendran a destruirnos 
si se molestan porque no sacrificamos ninios (si, los incas hacian 
sacrificios infantiles). Te guste o no, la escritura es importantisima para 
la humanidad, nos permite registrar nuestra cultura, nuestra historia, 
nuestras historias (literatura) nos permite comunicar ideas complejas como 
la ciencia y la matematica a generaciones posteriores e incrementar asi 
nuestro conocimiento mas alla de lo que permite el tiempo de una vida 
humana; sin escritura, una sociedad esta condenada a caer en la niebla de 
los mitos, tradiciones orales y, eventualmente, al olvido de su historia, 
sus conocimientos y su propia existencia; si sabemos lo que sabemos de las 
sociedades andinas hoy, es precisamente porque los espanioles se dieron el 
trabajo de registrar todo lo que veian y las historias que les contaban, 
por escrito (de los aztecas, por ejemplo, sabemos mas porque tenian su 
popol vuh en que ellos mismos cuentan  sus tradiciones) Acerca de su 
arquitectura, eso se llama neolitico (lo que sigue al paleolitico, o era de 
las cavernas), y es un periodo que  el resto del mundo ya habia superado 
hacia no cientos, sino miles de anios; no me parece poco lo que hicieron 
sin la rueda, lo que no me parece es que lo siguieran haciendo en pleno 
siglo XVI. Y nada mas extremista que decir que los incas no mentian, si 
existieron esas famosas 3 leyes (no seas ladron, ocioso, mentiroso), es 
precisamente porque habia gente que robaba,  que no trabajaba y gente que 
mentia... Tienes razon, con extremismos no llegamos a nada; pero somos 
decendientes de esas culturas y tambien de los espanioles, y sin que estos 
nos conectaran al resto del mundo, no conocerias ni la computadora por la 
que me escribes, de hecho no podrias ni escribirme, sino que estariamos, 
tanto tu como yo, construyendo nuestras casas con barro, piedra y caca de 
llama (no es broma, esos eran los materiales de construccion en los andes 
para la gente ordinaria, fuera de la ciudadela imperial).
comments.author: Niidea1986

comments.text:
+Niidea1986 es cierto no somos ni incas ni aztecas ni etc... somos los 
descendientes de esas culturas y no es que estemos de odio y de 
resentimientos sino es que se está analizando la historia que si no te das 
cuenta aún en la actulidad ese tipo de explotación existe. Sí, se adoraba

religionas existentes mejores? Por lo menos lo adoraban y respetaban la

extremismos no se llega a nada, lo que pasó quedó en el pasado.

comments.text:
+Bastián Rodríguez Saludos, no hay forma de que me lea toda esa mierda del 
primer comentario (y menos aun que me lo tome en serio). Esta bellamente 
redactado pero no es mas que mierda ultranacionalista trasnochada de algun 
pobre diablo. Carece de objetividad academica y no tiene conciencia de la 
realidad del momento historico (esto es, que ya pasamos la era de los 
imperios microcefalos, los pequenios paises Europeos jamas volveran a estar 
a cargo del mundo)   ... Pero tambien abunda mierda ultranacionalista en 
las respuestas que hablan cojudeces de grandes civilizaciones precolombinas 
que los hibericos vinieron a destruir y explotar. Es cierto, vinieron y 
explotaron los recursos y a los indios; pero tambien es cierto que esas 
culturas eran primitivas, vivian en el neolitico en pleno 1500, 
adoradoraban del sol, no conocian el acero, la escritura (en los andes) y 
ni la rueda siquiera. Y la verdad es que, sin ese contacto con Europa que 
nos conectara al resto del mundo (y que lo mismo da si hubiese sido, 
Espania, Inglaterra, China o Portugal...de hecho, menos mal fue Espania, en 
ninguno de los otros imperios hubo un Fray Bartolome de las Casas que 
defendiera a los indios y ninguna otra corona se preocupo siquiera de 
discutir la legitimidad de su dominio, es decir, con cualquier  otro de los 
imperios de entonces, habriamos estado peor)   seguiriamos en ese estado. 
No somos incas, ni aztecas, ni chapetones, somos hijos de la historia; de 
nada sirve guardar resentimientos idiotas ni renegar de la circunstancias 
(buenas y malas) que tuvieron lugar hace 500-200 anios y nos trajeron a lo 
que somos hoy.

comments.text:
Lo que la boca de Púrusha dice o comanda (en este caso la monarquía 
española y para ser un poco más específico Isabel la Católica, acerca del 
buen trato a los nativos de américa, derechos humanos en su primitivo 
estado, etc ).

Sus brazos, piernas de Púrusha (Hernan Cortez, Lope de Aguirre... 
Comandantes, Almirantes, Gobernadores, Alcades ) No llevaron a cabo.

Y sus pies siempre terminan agotados y futigados por la jornada (esclavos, 
nativos etc...) lo cual termina de sucumbir, lo que les paso al imperio 
español y a muchos imperios.

Las razones son variadas una de ellas es que, estos hombres están en 
contacto directo con estos nativos y para ganar su apoyo recurren a la 
violencia (porque es lo que para estos conquistadores les ha funcionado 
desde su infancia), lo cual aleja a la reina de la "realidad" de la 
situacion. PERO ANYWAY!... 

Lo mas importante de esto no es conocer nuestra raices para saber a QUIEN 
DEBEMOS ODIAR, sino A DONDE QUEREMOS IR, evitando en lo mas posible repetir 
los errores del pasado (un cliché) y valorar un poco mas la vida.

comments.text:
+quetzalamaru Entonces dime porque en la guerra de independencia los pueblos nativos apoyaron al rey español contra los criollos? porque hubieron titulos dados a nativos por los que se les hacían nobles? porque se construyeron universidades para preservar la cultura? porque si te vas a america norte cuesta encontrar nativos i en centro y el sur este lleno? porque en cádiz los hispanoamericanos tenían representación y eran tratados como territorio español? porque Isabel II legislo que no se podía esclabizar a los nativos? si tan pobre y depauperada estava por que La revolución americana se sustentó en la moneda española (que por casualidad era la mas fuerte) que acabaría siendo el dolar(de echo mantiene símbolos)? porque los impuestos en las Américas eran mas bajos que en la península?... podría seguir así horas. Desde luego no fue un camino de rosas pero hijo abre los ojos luego libros de derecho y historia que no hacen daño! Porque hay algo que se llama la historia negra de españa que básicamente la escribieron holandeses, ingleses, franceses... Y en este video se nota el legado de a história negra. Si eres hispano abre libros y lee arañas sobre personas que mezclaron la sangre nativa i la española y te sentirás orgulloso de tus raízes porque se hicieron grandes cosas y hubo mucha prosperidad a diferencia de lo que se intenta vender en este vídeo. Informarte sobre los Tercios, Quevedo, Góngora, Garcilaso... sinembargo La catástrofe demográfica quesufrió el continente americano desde 1492, el año del Descubrimiento de Cristóbal Colón, es un hecho irrefutable. Antes de la llegada de los españoles se ha estimado tradicionalmente que la poblacióndel continente se encontraba entre los 40 millones y 100 millones. No obstante,el hispanista venezolano Ángel Rosenblat argumenta en su estudio «La población de América en 1492: viejos y nuevos cálculos» (1967) que la cifra no pasaría de 13 millones, concentrándose los mayor grupos en las actuales regiones de México y de Perú, ocupadas por el Imperio azteca y el Inca respectivamente. Sea una cifra u otra, la disminución demográfica fue dramática: el 95 % de la población dounidense H. F. Dobyns.La sangría demográficahay que buscarla en dos factores: ellas bajas causadas por la guerra, el desplome de las actividades económicas y los grandes desplazamientos poblaciones) y las enfermedades. Los habitantes deAmérica habían permanecido aislados del resto total de América murió en los primeros 130 años después de la llegada de Colón, según el investigador esta del mundo y pagaron a un alto precio el choque biológico. Cuando las enfermedades traídas desde Europa, que habían evolucionado durante miles de años de Humanidad, entraron encontacto con el Nuevo Mundo causaron miles de muertes ante la fragilidad biológica de sus pobladores.Un sencillocatarro nasal resultaba mortal para muchos indígenas. El resultado fue la muerte de un porcentaje estimadodel 95% de la población nativa americana existente a lallegada deColón debido a las enfermedades, según los cálculos delecólogo Jared Diamond. Entre 1518 y 1519 acabó con prácticamente toda la población local. Esta misma epidemia fueintroducida por los hombres de HernánCortés en México y, tras arrasar Guatemala, bajo hasta el corazón del Imperio Inca en 1525, donde diezmó a la mitad de la población. Precedido por la

viruela, @20130524 fue el golpe final a un imperio que seencontraba colapsado por las enfermedades. La epidemia de viruela fue seguida por el sarampión (1530-31), el tifus en 1546, y la gripe en 1558. La difteria, las paperas, la sífilis y la peste neumónica también golpearon fuerte en lapoblación. Así que nada de historieta anglosajona y mas datos de historiadores y geógrafos y no alborotadores populistas como maduro o chavistas un poco de seriedad y rigor.

caused by European interactions. Cultures (except for tribes living in 
dense jungles and high mountains) are either completely forgotten or 
assimilated with Spanish culture so much so that they are unrecognizable.

mentioned did. It is merely discussed in his other videos. This statement,

atrocities. The Spanish, like any of the colonial powers, did a lot of 
horrible things to the natives in their provinces (European interests 
always came first before the natives, that is the trend of this era). If 
you are familiar with the Spanish Black Legend then you should also be 
familiar with the Spanish White Legend.

Just because this video showed the negative ramifications of the Spanish 
Empire does not mean that this video is an anti-Spain propaganda.  John 
Green is one of the most liberal historian in YouTube (you will notice that 
if you bothered to watch his U.S. History videos) he's anti-imperialism be 
it American, Spanish or British. Seriously, what would be the point of 
making an anti-Spain propaganda video? History in it's nature is biased and 
most of the time governments are the ones that decide which history are 
going to be taught in schools not the Board of Education or that nation's 
equivalent of it. This is usually done in order to increase national pride 
(As an example, President Marcos, ruled the Philippines from 1965-1986, 
changed so much of the Philippines' history that until today historians are 
still figuring which are false and which are true all in the name of 
national pride.).

Colonialism had a lot of negative effects for those that got afflicted by

powers did horrible things to their subjects none exempted from that. Of 
course, it is mostly because of certain individuals and their ambitions

The Mita system, as used by the Incas, is different when it was used by the 
Spaniards. When the Incas used the Mita system it is more like a mandatory 
community service with a high chance of the conscripted person to go home. 
They did works that are for the benefit of the community (roads, temples, 
farms, etc...) and not for the greed of some high ranking individuals. When 
the Spaniards used the Mita system it is mandatory slave labor with a high 
percentage of the conscripted person to never coming home. The Spanish 
ultimately used and exploited the Mita system for personal gains not for 
the good of the community. The Incas did not use money or trade like the 
Spanish do. Think of the Mita system, under Inca rule, as a way to pay 
taxes through physical labor and goods that are made by the Mita system are 
given back to the people (the Incas are a welfare people). If people did 
die of exhaustion, then they must be too few or too far in between. But, in 
the end, the Inca's used the Mita system for the benefit of its people 
while the Spanish used/exploited the Mita system for the wealth of Spain.

Well because basically the positive aspects of Spanish Imperialism have

Spanish colonization of what today is the Philippines is our indigenous 
women were relegated far deeper into the background when they in fact had 
crucial political (and divine) roles before they came to our shores in the 
15th century. They also extinguished a large component of our native 
culture and would have been probably intermixed with Spanish cultural 
imprints and barely identifiable today.

However, aside from technology from Europe and new cash crops from the 
Americas, Christianization of much of the islands repelled encroachment of 
Islam northwards all the way from what are today Indonesia. The Spaniards, 
who also found economic benefit from gaining control over the still 
non-Muslim and Islamized natives, were able to counter frequent raids of 
Sultanates which profit on slave trades with other empires and kingdoms 
across Southeast Asia.

comments.text:
+Wintutos 
Excuse you? The British and those "Americans"? Your terminology could be 
offensive to others.


I agree with +I Am. Many people have learned things in from different 
points of view. There is not a need to disparage someone or their ways of 
thinking just because you disagree. Many of the things you state are biased 
towards your viewpont; by arguing, you are not going to accomplish anything 
but a trade of insults.


1. There is real, irrevocable proof (if you aren't convinced, go research) 
such as letters, journal entries, paintings, primary documents that all 
prove that the Aztecs and Incas were conquered.


2. Basic United States history: John Green doesn't mention the U.S. 
revolution for independence because this is the sixteenth century! The U.S. 
fight for independence is in the eighteenth century, about two-thousand 
years from this current point in time being addressed in this video. Second 
of all, this is world history, not U.S. history.
The United States had no debt at the time. It was under England. The French 
were the ones that helped the United States fight the U.K. Spain actually 
refused to get involved; by staying neutral, it would not provoke anyone's 
anger. France were allies with the U.S. while Spain was not involved. I 
suggest that you watch Crash Course U.S. history to keep your information 
straight.


3. John Green is attempting to summarize the history of the world in a way 
that is easy to understand. He cannot possibly address every single event 
or said word in the history of the world. Of course he will leave out some 
things that he will address later, like the reign of Queen Elizabeth I. In 
fact, John Green said, "More on that later."


4. John Green explains world history in a way that is easy to understand. 
Naturally, he draws from sources that must be somewhat reliable, as he is 
sharing this information with the general public of people all throughout 
the world. He teaches about what he has been taught; although he has 
character and is indeed American he has no outstated bias toward any party 
or against any group. John Green most likely has a different outlook on 
history than you. You shouldn't complain about how his viewpoint is 
different. Not everyone will agree with someone's perspective.


John Green has put forth much effort in making these videos for the 
beneficence of others, and you should respect that. If you don't agree with 
him, don't watch his videos.


Thank you, and I trust that you will not respond with an insult, as to do 
so would be highly ignominious of you.


Source: PhD in History

comments.text:
To attempt to stay unbiased I will only reply with the facts I have read 
(granted, they are online facts).

Elisabeth (or Elizabeth I) decreed that any man who step foot in Britain 
was free, effectively ridding Britain of slavery. (This is rivaled by other 
sites which state she just disallowed Africans from being in Britain). The 
practice continued in the Americas until it's eventual abolition in 1833.

John does not specifically mention the Maya, but If you can add a part of 
the video where he does I will edit this. As for the Inca and Aztec, 
intentional extermination is arguable at best, however the killing of many 
natives of mesoamerica is fairly well documented. Unintentionally, the 
Spanish conquistadors Pizarro and Cortes killed many Inca and Aztecs, 
respectively, through infection mainly by smallpox. Through the turmoil 
that ensued, already following deaths within both hierarchies, the Spanish 
were able to conquer both empires with relative ease. Although little is 
understood of Cortes' motivations, Pizarro's motivations can be directly 
traced to the apparent wealth of the Inca.

Finally, Spain was in fact a fair part of the American Revolutionary War on 
the side of the colonies. This however occurs nearer to the late 18th 
century, which John barely begins to touch upon, ending mostly within the 
17th century (as provided by the video description).

comments.author: Matthew Abely

comments.text:
+slicedtoad I never said that modernization as we know it would have 
occurred without colonialism. Note the words "necessary" and "precursor."

I contend that global modernization itself is not a necessary precursor of 
technological development. But the word "modernization" is ambiguous; I 
mean "Westernization," which in historical times entailed forced 
dissemination (or, to conjure the metaphor of rape, insemination) of 
Western values and the marginalization of all cultures that rejected them 
-- obviously, it's closely related to colonialism.

So, let's consider a universe without European imperialism, and, more 
interestingly, without the widespread industrialization and the 
exploitative multinational corporations that would eventually result from 
it. Significant technological developments would still be possible. How? 
Through trade, limited industry, invention, serendipity, stuff that humans 
have always had.

That's not to say that in such a universe we would have had the Internet by 
the year 2000.
Nor is it to say that, given a few extra centuries to develop, the 
hypothetical world would become like ours, with millions or billions of 
devices, burgers, department stores, and suburban sprawls, all acquired at 
the cost of the health of the biosphere; indeed, such a world requires 
ecologically dangerous levels of industrialization and corporatism, which 
in the previous paragraph I banned.

But there could be computers, and whatnot.

In the third paragraph of your post, you remind us that the current, mostly 
Westernized world, despite all of its "modern luxuries," is flawed. You 
mention that there's still exploitation and a lot of economic inequality, 
and I'd like to add unsustainability to the list. For the planet's sake, we 
ought to start localizing, rather than globalizing, the economy, to aim at 
something close to the alternate universe that I've described, one that is 
less materially wealthy but less dangerous too. Perhaps in the future we 
will be forced to do so, or maybe we'll be stupid enough to put domes 
around our cities and let everything else rot.
comments.author: Joshua Chen

comments.text:
+Joshua Chen I don't know. It'd be difficult to argue that various 
undesirable to atrocious historical events didn't at least speed up the 
modernization process.

Slavery, colonialism and other systems that hinge on exploitation can't be 
justified ethically. But economically... they've been pretty successful.

The other mistake we tend to make when talking about "the horrors of 
history" is that we idealize the current world. Modern luxuries are awesome 
but they're *still* dependant on exploitation and nowhere close to being 
available to everyone. Food isn't even distributed properly yet.
comments.author: slicedtoad

comments.text:
Yes. I doubt that the suffering caused by colonialism, or even colonialism 
itself, was a necessary precursor of the Internet or other modern luxuries.

comments.text:
I'll give a big and proper answer.

There were definite reasons behind human sacrifices. Even though it was not 
uncommon, sacrifices were definitely not random. People were 'chosen' to be 
sacrificed. It was considered BIG thing even in those times. So, why the 
sacrifices?

1. Celebrations - Sacrifice prisoners of war after winning a war - The 
basic mentality behind this was to curb the chances of a future rebellion 
and as a side-benefit, you appease you war gods! A noteworthy thing is this 
was human sacrifice on MASS scale. Hundreds and thousands would be forced 
to jump into fire or whatever...

2. Cultural Beliefs - Sacrifice the slaves with the corpse of their 
masters. (With the mentality that they needed to serve them in afterlife as 
well)

3. Agricultural profits - This was mostly animal sacrifices to appease the 
'Rain-Gods'. Animal sacrifices were also common after the completion of big 
projects as a sign and wish for good luck; like building of a bridge, 
temple, etc.

4. Getting an impossible task done as a desperate measure - Sacrifices made 
when the society feels completely helpless. eg. You want to win a war where 
you know you have absolutely no chance! Such were the cases when the 
society would give away the best of everything they had. This was also the 
situations when the most beautiful and virgin girls of the place were 
sacrificed to make the gods favour them instead of their enemies.

5. Rebels - Well, this is simple; you preach against the religion or 
leader, the priest blames you for all the evil happening around, wants you 
dead! Although this was more like a punishment sacrifice but it's still a 
sacrifice as it is supposed to bring order in the region by pacifying god.

The people who were sacrificed weren't supposed to be 'terrorized'; they 
were either considered objects (like slaves) or they were sacrificed for 
the higher good of humanity (read as higher benefit of that particular 
society). The basic idea of human sacrifice was to appease the gods. And 
you just cannot justify sacrificing the priests or the "God's Messenger" to 
appease him. Right?

comments.text:
Not Holy because while it was supposed to be an arm of the Church, it 
eventually became as independent as other Christian kingdoms, not Roman, 
because, obviously, it was primarily German, and not an Empire because it 
didn't really have the central administration characteristic of empires,but 
rather a loose collection of central European polities with an elected 
"Emperor".  

Now of course, there's a reason for each of those names.  Holy, because it 
was originally established by the papacy, during the early expansion of 
Christianity,  Roman because it gained its authority from Rome (originally) 
and was the champion of Roman catholicism, and an Empire because, at that 
time, "Empire" was used to refer to successor states to the Roman Empire, 
such as the Byzantine and Carolingian Empires, and had little to do with 
how the nation was administered.  This is why Kingdoms that became 
extremely powerful still called themselves kingdoms instead of Empires, 
despite military and territorial superiority to neighboring "empires". 
 Even Napoleon had to have a ceremony with the pope in order to call 
himself "Emperor" despite his conquests and the nature of his 
administration.  

The modern sense of an empire being a diverse array of territories 
centrally administered by a core nation only developed in the early modern 
era, hence why Voltaire was the one who originally coined the phrase that 
the HRE was "neither Holy, Roman, nor an Empire"

comments.text:
Cool fact about the Incan Empire. The native people (Uros) that lived in 
what is now Peru/Bolivia built a series of artificial islands out of reeds 
and sailed out to the middle of Lake Titicaca to evade the Incan Empire as 
they took over their lands. They live primarily off of fish and constantly 
restructure their islands/boats by discarding old dead reeds and fixing 
them up with new fresh reeds. They live on these reed-islands to this day 
and you can visit them in person and buy their tourist stuff.﻿

comments.text:
One thing I've noticed with these Crash Course histories is that everyone 
enjoys them...until an episode comes up that concerns THEIR COUNTRY.

When the Kievan Rus/Grand Duchy of Muscovy episode was uploaded, all of a 
sudden we saw a tidal wave of Russians rushing to type how biased and wrong 
the video was.

Now we see the same thing, an episode concerning the Spanish Empire and, 
instead of just accepting that it caused a hell of a lot of suffering for 
many people, it's a barrage of 'This is hate!', 'Why don't you talk about 
the other counties, they did bad things too!', 'This is anti-Spanish 
propaganda'. It's pathetic.

Yes, the British Empire committed many atrocities against people within the 
empire, the Dutch apparently also did so, as well as the Portuguese, yet 
somehow because Crash Course has dared to make an episode specifically 
about the Spanish Empire all of a sudden it's 'hate' and 'anti-Spanish 
propaganda'? The Spanish atrocities can be excused because there wasn't an 
equal focus on other countries? It's an episode devoted to Spain and its 
empire, of course the focus is going to be Spain itself.

I'm also willing to bet that when the negative aspects of other nations 
histories, the Dutch or the British for example, come up in later episodes, 
we won't see the Spanish apologists leaping to their defence, it's only 
when Spain comes up that the "outrage" must begin because someone has dared 
to talk about Spanish history.﻿

comments.text:
+Lastof1AndAll Man, it's been over a month since this conversation has 
started. I really hate this new comment system.

To start off, I'm part Cree. My ancestors were still just as affected by 
the advent of colonialism as any might be. On the other hand, I'm also part 
Belgian, so my ancestry also perpetrated the worst example of colonialism 
on Earth. These influences have lead me to have to look into what 
colonialism actually meant and its factors whenever I try to look at my 
family line.

To call the Sicut Judaeis PR, however, betrays an ignorance of the Church's 
inner workings since the Bulls were met with great opposition, and was only 
one of several over the course of the Middle Ages. The Bulls were often in 
response to the abuses of the Jewish people by the monarchies of Europe 
(who liked to borrow money from the Jews and then expel them) or the 
peasantry (who were, as far as history was concerned, usually monstrous).

The Church also historically opposed the treatment of the natives for most 
of its history - the friar with Cortez had been trying to get as many 
natives spared as he could. This has historically been the truth. The 
Church may have indeed been paternalistic to the Natives, which is indeed, 
not right, but they were certainly never hostile or malicious towards them. 
(by the way, the old Pope was a duffer for saying what he did about the 
natives).

Now, we come to the new Pope, Pope Francis I. The thing about the Pope is 
that it's a political office as much as it is a religious one. That means 
that there are certain limitations on the Pope's power that don't appear on 
paper. The Pope's best chance is not to try and strongarm the conservative 
members of the Church because that will breed reactionary sentiment and 
make it far, far worse when the next Pope comes. What Pope Francis I has to 
do, and what he is doing, is sewing the seeds of a more liberal, tolerant 
Church that will be determined by those who, inspired by Francis' words, 
join the clergy and those who are of a more moderate sentiment being swayed 
to his position. He can't just undo all the doctrine in a day because that 
wouldn't work, it would just be immediately undone, and that's why I feel 
like your criticism of Francis I is unfair.

The Church is, and always has been, an organisation of fundamentally good 
intentions. I was born into a more or less Atheist household and converted 
into it because of the good I saw in it. I'm biased, I admit that. But on 
that note, I don't think Atheism needs to stand in opposition to the Church 
- Atheists have found the evidence lacking and thus religion is not for 
them. That is a perfectly fair stance to take and no one should begrudge 
them for it, but they don't need to further define themselves by 
specifically opposing the Church which has, historically, tried to be a 
good thing.

Go ahead and keep calling it out, though. So long as it's from a good 
conscience that it's done, then I can't fault you. To treat the Church as 
infallible is a terrible thing and frankly, it needs good people to notice 
the bad and say "Hey, whatcha doing?" if only to keep it honest, which it 
needs given the power it has over so many people. I merely seek to defend 
it from what I see as unfair criticisms, not all of them are unfair, though.

comments.text:
I apologise, I flew into the old blue blood rage. But what I mean is that 
the general position of the Catholic Church was one of benevolence as in 
general, the Catholic Church members were educated, and thus generally more 
compassionate than the average peasant. More often than not, atrocities 
committed in its name were done by lay people, whether they were monarchs 
or most often, peasants (as a cursory glance at history will tell you, 
peasants are generally just kinda awful people in general). 

The Church itself is, while not entirely blameless, a beacon of light and 
decency throughout most of history. The issue is that the secular followers 
were generally not. The worst crimes against one's fellow man during the 
Crusades were not supported by the clergy, but instead acts perpetrated by 
the common man. In general the Church created a moral grounding for people 
who worked within it (But again, not always), that didn't necessarily 
spread to followers. Hence, when Protestantism came around and gave 
religious power to the peasantry, all the worst religious atrocities 
occurred in Europe. (One could realistically claim Martin Luther was the 
man who started the German States on the path to the Holocaust.)

comments.text:
The task of keeping the rate of inflation low and stable is usually given 
to monetary authorities. Generally, these monetary authorities are the 
central banks that control monetary policy through the setting of interest 
rates, through open market operations, and through the setting of banking 
reserve requirements.
comments.author: Stella Maris

comments.text:
Today, most economists favor a low and steady rate of inflation. Low (as 
opposed to zero or negative) inflation reduces the severity of economic 
recessions by enabling the labor market to adjust more quickly in a 
downturn, and reduces the risk that a liquidity trap prevents monetary 
policy from stabilizing the economy.
comments.author: Stella Maris

comments.text:
Low or moderate inflation may be attributed to fluctuations in real demand 
for goods and services, or changes in available supplies such as during 
scarcities, as well as to changes in the velocity of money supply measures; 
in particular the MZM ("Money Zero Maturity") supply velocity. However, the 
consensus view is that a long sustained period of inflation is caused by 
money supply growing faster than the rate of economic growth.
comments.author: Stella Maris

comments.text:
Some economists maintain that high rates of inflation and hyperinflation 
are caused by an excessive growth of the money supply, while others take 
the view that under the conditions of a liquidity trap, large injections 
are "pushing on a string" and cannot cause significantly higher inflation. 
Views on which factors determine low to moderate rates of inflation are 
more varied.
comments.author: Stella Maris

comments.text:
Positive effects include ensuring that central banks can adjust real 
interest rates (to mitigate recessions), and encouraging investment in 
non-monetary capital projects.
comments.author: Stella Maris

comments.text:
Inflation's effects on an economy are various and can be simultaneously 
positive and negative. Negative effects of inflation include an increase in 
the opportunity cost of holding money, uncertainty over future inflation 
which may discourage investment and savings, and if inflation is rapid 
enough, shortages of goods as consumers begin hoarding out of concern that 
prices will increase in the future.
comments.author: Stella Maris

comments.text:
A chief measure of price inflation is the inflation rate, the annualized 
percentage change in a general price index (normally the consumer price 
index) over time.
comments.author: Stella Maris

comments.text:
In economics, inflation is a rise in the general level of prices of goods 
and services in an economy over a period of time. When the general price 
level rises, each unit of currency buys fewer goods and services. 
Consequently, inflation reflects a reduction in the purchasing power per 
unit of money – a loss of real value in the medium of exchange and unit of 
account within the economy.
comments.author: Stella Maris

theft and animal rustling were outlawed, and the Mongol Empire under 
Genghis Khan even established a massive lost-and-found system. Harsh 
penalties including a retribution of nine times the original value of 
stolen goods helped deter theft on Mongol roads. The Yassa also decreed 
complete religious freedom, ensuring that Buddhists, Muslims, Christians, 
etc., were all allowed to travel freely throughout the empire;
comments.author: Big Nutjob

comments.text:
Islamic methods of mathematics, astronomy, and science made their way to 
Africa, East Asia and Europe during the Pax Mongolica too. The secular code 
of Mongol law, known as the Yassa (Great Law), decreed strict rules and 
punishments in many areas of the Mongolian Empire's society, especially 
those areas concerning trade and commerce. The Yassa helped suppress the 
traditional causes of tribal feuding and war, thus helping to ensure a 
peaceful trading and traveling environment;
comments.author: Big Nutjob

comments.text:
Increasing trade and commerce meant that the respective nations and 
societies increased their exposure to new goods and markets, thus 
increasing the GDP of each nation or society that was involved in the trade 
system. Methods of paper-making and printing made their way from China to 
Europe. During the Pax Mongolica rudimentary banking systems were 
established, and money changing and credit extension were common, resulting 
in large amount of merchant wealth.
comments.author: Big Nutjob

comments.text:
On the Silk Road traveled caravans with Chinese silk; pepper, ginger, 
cinnamon, and nutmeg came to the West from the Spice Islands via the 
transcontinental trade routes. Eastern diets were introduced to Europeans 
as well. Indian muslins, cottons, pearls, and precious stones were sold in 
Europe, as well as weapons, carpets, and leather goods from Iran. Gunpowder 
was also introduced to Europe from China. In the opposite direction, 
Europeans sent silver, fine cloth, horses, linen, and other goods.
comments.author: Big Nutjob

comments.text:
The new Mongol empire amalgamated the once isolated civilizations into a 
new continental system, and re-established the Silk Road as a dominant 
method of transportation. The unification of Eurasia under the Mongols 
greatly diminished the amount of competing tribute gatherers throughout the 
trade network and assured greater safety and security in travel. European 
merchants like Marco Polo made their way from Europe to China on the 
well-maintained and well-traveled roads.
comments.author: Big Nutjob

comments.text:
This meant that an extremely large part of the continent was united under 
one political authority. As a result, the trade routes used by merchants 
became safe for travel, resulting in an overall growth and expansion of 
trade from China in the east to Britain in the west. Thus, the Pax 
Mongolica greatly influenced many civilizations in Eurasia during the 13th 
and 14th centuries. Before the Mongols' rise, the Old World system 
consisted of isolated imperial systems.
comments.author: Big Nutjob

comments.text:
The conquests of Kublai Khan and his successors effectively connected the 
Eastern world with the Western world, ruling a territory from Southeast 
Asia to Eastern Europe. The Silk Road, connecting trade centers across Asia 
and Europe, came under the sole rule of the Mongol Empire. At its height, 
the Mongolian empire stretched from Sakhalin Island in the east to Budapest 
in the west, from Rus' in the north to Tibet in the south.
comments.author: Big Nutjob

comments.text:
Ever Heard about Pax Mongolica? Pax Mongolica means "Mongol Peace" coined 
by Western scholars to describe the stabilizing effects of the conquests of 
the Mongol Empire on the social, cultural, n economic life of the 
inhabitants of the vast Eurasian territory that the Mongols conquered in 
the 13th and 14th centuries. it is used to describe the eased communication 
and commerce the unified administration helped to create, and the period of 
relative peace that followed the Mongols' vast conquests.

comments.text:
The Inca and previous Andean civilizations had already adapted to the 
climate very well. For one, Andean peoples have larger hearts and more 
efficient cardio-pulmonary systems. Terracing, irrigation, and other 
strategies had been used for thousands of years to farm a lot of food from 
the very vertical terrain. The Mit'a system allowed for a large labour 
force without disrupting agricultural production or fomenting unrest. 
Macchu Picchu was built as an estate for Pachacuti c. 1450

weigh in more than 50 tons. You would find it hard to round up a bunch of

is thinner and farming vegetation is sparse.

comments.text:
No, the Mita was never used for mining. Mining required specified 
experience, and miners were paid salaries by law since the mines themselves 
were the Crown's property, and those salaries were made of raw silver which 
the indigenous people would convert into silver. The Mita was used for 
supportive work, mostly water and food supply to Potosi which was not 
available then.

The problem Spain had in dealing with its wealth is am example for the 
efficiency of markets controlled by the state vs. private markets. Because 
colonists preferred to trade with pirates and use non-Spanish banking 
systems rather than having to cash in their silver for low-intrest bonds, 
the Crown never saw its share of the silver produced. But we've also seen 
now that private industry hasn't done any real good for Latin America, 
either. Great video, I've got a midterm for this on Friday!

comments.text:
Well, that depends. On a lot of things. To use the UK as a case study, the 
privatisation of utilities (gas, electricity, and especially water) has 
yielded few benefits, and in the case of water has been detrimental, with 
prices going sky-high with the creation of local, private monopolies. The 
privatisation of the railways, too, hasn't made them better. Similarly, if 
the country is trying to help a new industry grow, a state monopoly can be 
beneficial because t prevents the company from failing
comments.author: Bryn Walsh

more from principal than practicality.

comments.text:
Spanish rule in the Philippines, relatively stable, uneventful & peaceful 
compared to the Americas because the Spaniards made blood compacts w/ the 
pre-existing Malay nobles, who were granted royal titles & vast expanses of 
land under a decree of the Spanish crown - the Principalia class. This 
meant much of the colony was still controlled by Principalia (who 
intermarried with Spaniards, creating the Mestizo class). It worked until 
they decided to piss off the Mestizo class by killing Jose Rizal.
