comments.text:
I believe that competition is a n old way to organize our economies and 
humanities productivity. One that causes a lot of heartache and harm. There 
has to be a more modern way to organize our technological revolutions. I 
see some inklings in how innovation produces technology which organizes our 
economies. But i am afraid that without a serious goal we will create and 
advance our collective cause for pleasure and power only rather than 
advancement.
comments.author: Mike Zalez

comments.text:
I appreciate your consideration of Pre-columbian societies as viable for 
consideration. What has happened cannot be undone, or thought too much 
about, only learned from to prevent repeating mistakes. We must all guard 
our ultra-modern society's progression into the even more modern age. And 
we must not repeat the same missteps that crumbled past civilizations. 
There is a great prize to be won if society matures enough to the point to 
realize what that prize is.
comments.author: Mike Zalez

comments.text:
I don't think it benefits to wander into thoughts of supposition. What has 
happened cannot be undone. So to think about how to undo it is pointless, 
unless you are dabbing into science fiction. Our energies a better spent in 
what is occurring now, and how that may affect the near and later future, 
and how it changes (for the better i hope) our society as a whole. I 
recommend Shadyac's documentary "I AM".
comments.author: Mike Zalez

comments.text:
It's great that you're so interested in world history, but you have to be 
careful about seeking a 'complete' version of history. History is just 
story telling, and a story can be told in many different ways. One of the 
best things you can do is to read many different versions of the story that 
is history, i recommend Howard Zinn's book.
comments.author: Mike Zalez

comments.text:
I absolutely agree with the idea that we can now move forward and progress

start taking on some Grand Projects and Initiatives.

comments.text:
Well it depends on what topics interest you. If you want more on the 
Spanish in Meso-America then I recommend J H Elliott's "Empires of the 
Atlantic World" (which also talks about the English in North America which 
is really interesting) and John Lynch's "Spain 1516-1598: From Nation State 
to World Empire". If you want something specifically about Cortes and the 
fall of the Aztec Empire then I highly recommend Ross Hassig's "Mexico and 
the Spanish Conquest" - it's well written and accessible.
comments.author: nelsynoo

comments.text:
I think the statement was it worth it, is actually rather useless. Good 
things can lead to poor outcomes and vica versa. Who was it worth it for? 
The only people the statement can be applied to were the people who gained 
from it and their answer depends on their empathy. Can we learn from it 
sure. Was it worth it? Now? Well we gained from it. fundamentaly what's 
being asked is. Do you value your life more than the suffering of others. 
Of which the answer is yes for all us.

there is not enough to say about them to fill an entire episode.

capital-H History - they had no written records because they had no

prior to contact and the existence of mythological traces of ancient trade 
with trepang-hunters who might possibly have been from China but were more 
likely to be from Sulawesi does not a whole episode make.

comments.text:
Dear John Green, Thanks to you and these videos, I was much better prepared 
for the final exam in my AP world history class. They were the best review 
material I had found and going in the day of the test I was much happier 
having heard the material in a new and entertaining way. I got the results 
in the mail the other day and my score was much better than I thought it 
would be and I have received college credit for the class! I just wanted to 
say thank you!

comments.text:
Actually the Aztecs didn't perform human sacrifice to "please" the gods. 
Not from their perspective at least. They saw it as an exchange of life 
between humans and the Sun god, which kept the Sun (as a god) living. In 
Aztec mythology a god sacrificed his life to become the Sun to end a 50 
year period of darkness. The Aztecs were following his example through 
their human sacrifice, not because they wanted to avoid disasters, at least 
disasters other than eternal darkness. :P

comments.text:
There are a lot of people mad at us over the lack of a full episode on the 
pre-Columbian people of the Americas, and a lot of people mad at us about 
the lack of Vikings. We also didn't discuss Indonesia before the arrival of 
Islam, or pre-European Australia, and lots of other things. It's an 
unfortunate reality that we just can't talk about all of world history in 
40 10-minute episodes. Hopefully we'll make more and learn more together 
down the road. -John

comments.text:
We talked about the Thirty Years War--albeit without calling it that--in 
this video. We're obviously going to skip or gloss over a lot of world 
history, but I'd argue the Seven years War is very important from a world 
historical perspective because it was the first truly global war (although 
as discussed in this video, the Thirty Years War had global impact as 
well). -John

No, that's ludicrous.Th Spanish and Portuguese were the only european

comments.text:
Well, a lot of libertarians don't favor the gold standard, to be fair. But 
yeah, pegging the health of your economy to precious metals is really 
problematic, because if a ship full of gold sinks, you experience 
deflation, and if there's a discovery of gold, you experience inflation. 
You want your inflationary risks tied to different, hopefully less 
arbitrary events. But that's for Crash Course Economics, which hopefully 
we'll teach someday soon! -John
comments.author: CrashCourse

comments.text:
It'll be discussed in episode 31, but y'all have to remember that we are 
going to skip or gloss over a lot of things so that we can discuss some 
things with depth and thoughtfulness and nuance. Our idea here isn't to 
teach you all of world history; our idea is to help you learn some of the 
interesting things that world history can offer, and some of the ways of 
thinking ABOUT our history that can be useful. -John
comments.author: CrashCourse

was the Carolingian Empire basically founded by Charlemange who managed to 
conquer a huge part of Western and Central Europe and was crowned the new 
Roman Emperor by the Pope. After his death the empire was divided into 
three parts: West Francia became France while Middle Francia and East 
Francia were later combined and expanded into the HRE. Although they 
considered the Carolingian Empire the first form of HRE.

comments.text:
Charles V didn't "unify Spain and Austria by becoming head of the Holy 
Roman Empire." He never unified the rule in the disparate parts of his 
domains, which is a large reason why none of them stayed together. Also, it 
was simply by birth that he owned them; becoming Emperor extended his 
(nominal) rule over the rest of the Holy Roman Empire, but his Austrian 
possessions (not synonymous with the Holy Roman Empire) were purely by 
right of being head of the House of Habsburg.

Why hasn't there been a video on the Protestant Reformation yet? You've 
danced around events that were important to it, such as the Holy Roman 
Empire and the Renaissance, but haven't touched on the Reformation. 
Although a religious event, the conflict between Protestant people and 
Catholic people during the 15-1600's led to major historical events, like 
the Thirty Years War and the English Civil War, and laid the groundworks 
for religious freedom as we know it today.

silver was mined in SA, by natives then melted down and cast into the 
object. Today, if you live in the USA, and have bought anything made from 
silver since the 1900's,you have an %85 chance of it being made-up of 
silver from SA,and a%15 of it from the silver mines in the USA. Gold and 
silver are almost always being re-cast over and over.There is a %15 chance 
of having silver from Greece,3,000BCE in any one peice of silver
